head.title: Ford Offering Credit Cards In Effort to Lure Car Buyers

hedline.hl1: Ford Offering Credit Cards In Effort to Lure Car Buyers

block.p: In the latest skirmish in the credit card wars, the Ford Motor Company said yesterday that one of its financial services units would offer a credit card as a marketing tool to help retain old Ford customers and attract new ones.

But the Chrysler Corporation may also be planning to enter the credit card business, according to The American Banker, a trade publication. Unlike the Ford program, Chrysler's effort would be for private-label cards that would not carry the Chrysler logo but rather the name of a furniture store or similar issuer, the publication said.

In the latest skirmish in the credit card wars, the Ford Motor Company said yesterday that one of its financial services units would offer a credit card as a marketing tool to help retain old Ford customers and attract new ones.

But the Chrysler Corporation may also be planning to enter the credit card business, according to The American Banker, a trade publication. Unlike the Ford program, Chrysler's effort would be for private-label cards that would not carry the Chrysler logo but rather the name of a furniture store or similar issuer, the publication said.
Officials of Chrysler, the nation's No. 3 auto maker, could not be reached for immediate comment yesterday.

Ford, the No. 2 car maker, plans to offer its credit card to "several hundred thousand" customers who have bought or leased a Ford car or light truck in the last three years, as well as to potential customers who might own a competing make, like the General Motors Corporation's Cadillac.

Ford said it planned to expand the program within a year to other customers, employees and the general public. "We'd like to offer it to anybody who's even thinking of driving a Ford," said Fredrick H. Stern, a spokesman for the Associates, the Ford subsidiary offering the card.

The Visa or Mastercard would carry no annual fee. The card would have an introductory six-month annual percentage rate of 15.9 percent and would rise afterward to 19.8 percent, a typical interest rate for bank cards. It would also offer an annual rebate of five-tenths of a percent to 1.5 percent of the value of purchases made with the card.
Ford said the rebates and the lack of an annual fee would substantially lower the card's cost to consumers.
The Associates, a unit of Ford's financial services group, has American assets of $18.8 billion. It has been issuing credit cards since 1978 and was acquired by Ford in 1989.
